awd_titl_txt: Stochastic Games for Intergenerational Equity in Mathematical Finance
awd_abstract_narration:
Intergenerational conflicts of interest are inevitable to wealth and resource management in a society. This problem is more pressing now than ever as demographic change has reached a pivotal point. The combined working-age population in developed countries is projected to shrink continuously until 2050, while the retired population will grow rapidly. The tension between the two cohorts, working and retired (or, young and old), is almost certain to exacerbate, as the wealth of the former is used to support the latter, under Social Security or many other pension schemes. Yet, the precise economic consequences are not that apparent. This project aims to elucidate how an evolving demographic structure affects financial planning in a society. This will be done at two different levels: one from the eyes of the competing young and old cohorts, the other from the panoramic perspective of a social planner, such as a government. Graduate students are involved in the project. 

The first part of the project investigates the interplay between the young and the old cohorts. It is formulated as a two-player nonzero-sum game in a stochastic Ramsey model, with the dynamics of demographic structure explicitly modeled. The goal is to understand how the two cohorts interact through their consumption and saving decisions, and how an evolving demographic structure affects their decisions, and the resulting welfare. Nash equilibrium strategies of the two cohorts will be found and analyzed through a system of coupled Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equations with non-Lipschitz coefficients. This demands new developments in stochastic differential games and viscosity solution techniques. The second part of the project handles the social planner's dilemma: a financial planning strategy deemed optimal today by the current society may not be optimal from the view of the society in the future, as the evolving demographics continuously change the overall societal preference. This leads to a new form of time-inconsistent problems, with non-exponential and time-dependent discount functions, which will be treated under an intra-personal game between current and future societies. A new method for time-inconsistency, called the fixed-point approach, is developed in the project. It provides a new machinery for constructing time-consistent strategies, while possessing the potential of less mathematical technicalities.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have developed new mathematical theories and techniques in order to understand how an evolving demographic structure affects financial planning in a society. There were two specific questions to answer: (i) How do the young and old cohorts (or, the working and retired cohorts), who compete for resources in a society, interact through their consumption behaviors? Specifically, how does the evolving demographics affect their interaction? (ii) With a changing demographic structure, how can a government devise a time-consistent financial planning policy, i.e. a policy that will be deemed desirable by not only the current society but the future ones as well? This is a pressing challenge because only time-consistent policies will be implemented over time. 

For question (i), we studied the interaction between the young and old cohorts using game theory. Specifically, each cohort maximizes its overall welfare by choosing an appropriate consumption rate. The more it consumes now, the happier it is right away, but at the same time the less resources left for economic development. There is then a tradeoff between short-term welfare from immediate consumption and long-term welfare from sustained economic growth. While this tradeoff is faced by both cohorts, the old has less incentive than the young to save resources for future economic growth. This results in a game between the two cohorts: they choose different consumption rates, which altogether determine the economic growth over time; this then affects their subsequent consumption decisions, which again influence the economic growth further down the road. Such modeling particularly extends the stochastic Ramsey problem in the economic growth theory from one uniform population to two competing sub-populations. Mathematically, we formulated this game using two backward stochastic differential equations (BSDEs) that are "coupled", which reflects the fact that the consumption decision of one cohort inherently depends on (affected by) that of the other cohort. We have developed new results for BSDEs with superlinear growth on unbounded random horizons, in order to find a Nash equilibrium between the two cohorts.  

For question (ii), we first observed that the design of a society's long-term financial planning strategy translates into a "time-inconsistent" optimization problem. How to resolve the involved time inconsistency (i.e., the conflict of interest between different generations in our case) has remained an unsettled mathematical challenge. The standard approach relies on a complicated system of nonlinear partial differential equations (PDEs), which can be quite difficult to solve in practice. In this project, we developed a brand-new methodology -- the fixed-point iterative approach -- to treat time inconsistency. This new approach completely circumvents the standard PDE method: it resolves time inconsistency conveniently via fixed-point iterations. We have applied our theory to well-known time-inconsistent scenarios in behavioral economics, such as decision making under non-exponential discounting, probability distortion, and model ambiguity. All this points to the general fact: the fixed-point iterative approach resolves time inconsistency with minimal technicalities.

This project has potentially valuable applications in policy making. The proposed game-theoretic setup and the newly-developed fixed-point iterative approach provide a theoretical framework for constructing a financial planning policy in a society that strikes a balance between the needs of the current and future generations. This can be instrumental to policy makers who work on long-term welfare management of the society. This project supported the training of three Ph.D. students in the Departments of Mathematics and Applied Mathematics at the University of Colorado Boulder. All of them successfully obtained their degrees and have continued to work in academia (as postdocs and instructors).
